snippet: The questioning of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad over economic mismanagement was the first interrogation of its kind since Iran’s 1979 revolution.
abstract: Lawmakers in Iran subject president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, to an unprecedented interrogation, questioning his economic policies, cabinet appointments and tense relationship with the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, in a publicly broadcast parliamentary session that seemed intended to humiliate the president in the final few years of his tenure; it is the first time since the 1979 Islamic Revolution that an Iranian president was required to appear before lawmakers to answer their questions.

byline.original: By RICK GLADSTONE and ALAN COWELL
byline.contributor: Rick Gladstone reported from New York, and Alan Cowell from London. J. David Goodman contributed reporting from New York, and Artin Afkhami from Boston.

lead_paragraph: The questioning of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad over economic mismanagement was the first interrogation of its kind since Iran’s 1979 revolution.

headline.main: Iran’s President Unfazed in Parliamentary Grilling
headline.print_headline: Iran’s President Unfazed In Parliamentary Grilling
